title: Whitney Eugene Thayer
text:
Whitney Eugene Thayer (December 11, 1838, <a href="Mendon%2C%20Massachusetts">Mendon, Massachusetts</a> – June 27, 1889, <a href="Burlington%2C%20Vermont">Burlington, Vermont</a>) was an American <a href="organist">organist</a> and <a href="composer">composer</a>.
Thayer gave his first concert just after the installation of the new <a href="organ%20%28music%29">organ</a> in the <a href="Boston%20Music%20Hall">Boston Music Hall</a> in 1863. An early student of <a href="John%20Knowles%20Paine">John Knowles Paine</a>, he advanced to studied organ and <a href="counterpoint">counterpoint</a> in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> with <a href="Carl%20August%20Haupt">Carl August Haupt</a> (who also taught Paine). After returning from Berlin he worked in <a href="Boston%2C%20Massachusetts">Boston</a> and later in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> as an organist. He was also a touring <a href="virtuoso">virtuoso</a>, organ teacher, and music writer.
Apart from a festive <a href="cantata">cantata</a> and a <a href="mass%20%28music%29">mass</a>, he composed numerous works for organ, <a href="art%20song">art song</a>s, and <a href="human%20voice">vocal</a> <a href="quartet">quartet</a>s.
